Portfolio Selection
READING There are a number of textbooks on portfolio selection which explain both Markowitz’s original theory and some ingenious simplified versions. See, for example: E
Of the three pioneering articles on the capital asset pricing model, Jack Treynor’s has never been published. The other two articles are: W
Capital Asset Prices: A Theory of Market Equilibrium under Conditions of Risk
The Valuation of Risk Assets and the Selection of Risky Investments in Stock Portfolios and Capital Budgets

container-title: Studies in the Theory of Capital Markets
title: The subsequent literature on the capital asset pricing model is enormous. The following book provides a collection of some of the more important articles plus a very useful survey by Jensen
The two most important early tests of the capital asset pricing model are: E
Risk, Return and Equilibrium: Empirical Tests

container-title: Studies in the Theory of Capital Markets
title: The Capital Asset Pricing Model: Some Empirical Tests
For a critique of empirical tests of the capital asset pricing model, see: R. Roll: “A Critique of the Asset Pricing Theory’s Tests; Part I: On Past and Potential Testability of the Theory

Much of the recent controversy about the performance of the capital asset pricing model was prompted by Fama and French’s paper. The paper by Black takes issue with Fama and French and updates the Black, Jensen, and Scholes test of the model: E
French: “The Cross-Section of Expected Stock Returns
Beta and Return
Breeden’s 1979 article describes the consumption asset pricing model, and the Breeden, Gibbons, and Litzenberger paper tests the model and compares it with the standard CAPM
An Intertemporal Asset Pricing Model with Stochastic Consumption and In-Visit us at www.mhhe.com/bm7e vestment Opportunities
Empirical Tests of the Consumption-Oriented CAPM
Arbitrage pricing theory is described in Ross’s 1976 paper
The Arbitrage Theory of Capital Asset Pricing
The most accessible recent implementation of APT is
Cost of Capital Using Arbitrage Pricing Theory: A Case Study of Nine New York Utilities
For an application of the Fama–French three-factor model, see: E
Industry Costs of Equity
In a survey of financial practice, Graham and Harvey found that 74 percent of firms always, or almost always, used the capital asset pricing model to estimate the cost of capital
The Theory and Practice of Corporate Finance: Evidence from the Field
FURTHER There is a good review article by Rubinstein on the application of the capital asset pricing model to READING capital investment decisions
A Mean-Variance Synthesis of Corporate Financial Theory
There have been a number of studies of the relationship between accounting data and beta. Many of these are reviewed in: G
CHAPTER 9 Capital Budgeting and Risk 245
For some ideas on how one might break down the problem of estimating beta, see: W
The Capital Asset Pricing Model: A ‘Multi-Beta’ Interpretation
Fama and French present estimates of industry costs of equity capital from both the CAPM and APT models. The difficulties in obtaining precise estimates are discussed in
Industry Costs of Equity
The assumptions required for use of risk-adjusted discount rates are discussed in
Risk-Adjusted Discount Rates and Capital Budgeting under Uncertainty

container-title: Good News and Bad News,” Journal of Finance
title: Capital Budgeting and the Capital Asset Pricing Model

container-title: MIT Program on the Pharmaceutical Industry
title: Myers and Howe estimated the average cost of bringing one new drug to market as about $300 million after tax. The estimate was based on R&D costs and success rates from the 1970s and 1980s, but adjusted for inflation through 1994
A Life-Cycle Model of Pharmaceutical R&D
For an excellent case study of break-even analysis, see: FURTHER U
Break-Even Analysis for Lockheed’s TriStar: An Application of Financial Theory

The Use of Decision Analysis in Capital Investment Problems
Merck’s use of Monte Carlo simulation is discussed
Scientific Management at Merck: An Interview with Judy Lewent

container-title: Cowles Foundation Discussion Paper No. 1303, Cowles Foundation for Research in Economics
title: Shiller also discusses behavioral explanations for the boom in R

Some countries experienced even larger falls than the United States. For example, prices fell by 46 percent in Hong Kong, 42 percent in Australia, and 35 percent in Mexico. For a discussion of the worldwide nature of the crash, see R
The International Crash of October 1987
Black Monday and the Future of Financial Markets, Richard D
The classic review articles on market efficiency are: FURTHER
Efficient Capital Markets: A Review of Theory and Empirical Work
Efficient Capital Markets: II
For evidence on possible exceptions to the efficient-market theory, we suggest: G
On the Predictability of Common Stock Returns: World-Wide Evidence
Martin Gruber’s Presidential Address to the American Finance Association is an interesting overview of the performance of mutual fund managers
Another Puzzle: The Growth in Actively Managed Mutual Funds

container-title: A. Shleifer: Inefficient Markets: An Introduction to Behavioral Finance
title: Andre Shleifer’s book and Robert Shiller’s paper provide a good introduction to behavioral finance. A useful collection of papers on behavioral explanations for market anomalies is provided in Richard Thaler’s book of readings, while Eugene Fama’s paper offers a more skeptical view of these behavioral theories
Human Behavior and the Efficiency of the Financial System
Market Efficiency, Long-Term Returns, and Behavioral Finance

container-title: Black Monday and the Future of Financial Markets

Dividend Policy, Growth and the Valuation of Shares

title: It includes four articles on the information content of dividends. The effect of differential rates of tax on dividends and capital gains is analyzed rigorously in the context of the capital asset pricing model in: M

title: FURTHER The pioneering work on the theory of capital structure is

Reply to Heins and Sprenkle

container-title: H. Miller: “Debt and Taxes,” Journal of Finance
title: Miller extends the MM model to personal as well as corporate taxes. DeAngelo and Masulis argue that firms with plenty of noninterest tax shields, for example, shields from depreciation, should borrow less. Graham’s estimates of the tax benefits of debt recognize the possibility that firms will not earn taxable profits in the future: M
Optimal Capital Structure under Corporate Taxation
How Big Are the Tax Benefits of Debt?

container-title: Privatization is reviewed in: W. L. Megginson and J
title: READING The papers by Kaplan and by Kaplan and Stein provide evidence on the evolution and performance of LBOs; Jensen, the chief proponent of the free-cash-flow theory of takeovers, gives a spirited and controversial defense of LBOs: S
The Effects of Management Buyouts on Operating Performance and Value
The Evolution of Buyout Pricing and Financial Structure (Or, What Went Wrong) in the 1980s
The Eclipse of the Public Corporation
From State to Market: A Survey of Empirical Studies on Privatization

note: See also the following survey article:
title: The Winter 1997 issue of the Journal of Applied Corporate Finance contains several articles on governance and control in different countries
A Survey of Corporate Governance
Here are five useful articles on corporate finance in Germany and Japan
Corporate Governance in an International Perspective: A Survey of Corporate Control Mechanisms among Large Firms in the U.S., U.K., Japan and Germany
Ownership and Control of German Corporations
The Role of Hostile Stakes in German Corporate Performance
Anatomy of a Governance Transformation: The Case of Daimler-Benz
The Governance Structure of the Japanese Keiretsu
Here are some interesting case studies pertinent to this chapter
Reinventing the Corporation: The Satellite Structure of Thermo Electron

Privatization and Efficiency: Industry Effects of the Sale of British Airways
Barbarians at the Gate: The Fall of RJR Nabisco
Beatrice: A Study in the Creation and Destruction of Value
Organizational Form and the Consequences of Highly Leveraged Transactions
